A weird phrase/play on words, but the message is true, I guess.

Begin by improving yourself, and you will no longer feel inadequate. There are many options when it comes to self-improvement; NoFap is just one of them. In addition to NoFap you should try and find a hobby or skill you enjoy doing, and become better at that (sports, writing, art, academics, etc. The list is endless). You can also find a goal you want to achieve, and focus on completing that goal (90 days NoFap, 90 days cold showers + meditation, lose X amount of weight, gain X amount of muscle, etc). Hope that helps, best of luck.

Yeah, trying to escape an addiction is hard. Even when things are going well porn can rear its ugly head and try to drag back down into hell. I've had relaspes just like you had, and went through the same experience of not doing anything and feeling like total shit. All we can do is accept our shortcoming, and move on with greater resolve.

I know you didn't say that, I was just clarifying what I agreed with/disagreed it. And since we're on the topic, does the badge change to a "1" after 10 days or 1 week? Thanks.

Well, I agree with him insofar that we should that we should tackle each day as it comes, live each day to our fullest. That said, I think not taking into account the past or future is foolish. Counting days allows us to see the progress we make on a grander scale. And looking toward a goal of say 90 days gives us something concrete to aim for. And I agree with you that a "relapse is okay" mentality is wrong to have. Like you said, this journey needs to be taken seriously, and a serious mindset is necessary to succeed.

Relapses and setbacks are not the end. It is through our struggles that we become stronger. Don't be distraught. Learn from your relapses, become even more motivated to fight them. This is the mentally I have, anyway.

Here's a basic blueprint for success:
1.) Work hard on making lifestyle changes, not just NoFap. 2.) Be patient and consistent. 3.) Enjoy the results as they come.
Best of luck.

I think he's trying to say that everyday is a new day, and we should tackle each day as it comes (rather than worry how long our streak is). I don't entirely agree with that statement, but I think that's the point he's trying to make.

True, but I think the possibility of the tower falling is actually a better analogy to life. I think we all can reach a moment where we hit rock bottom, and everything just falls apart. That said, just because the tower falls doesn't mean it's over; we can rebuild the tower, brick by brick, day by day, until we are once again standing tall.

Well, you could think of a relapse of taking out a brick of the Jenga tower. Keep on doing it, and the tower will eventually fall, and trying to rebuild from that point will be very difficult, though not impossible.
